ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I have learned to better read and write in Chinese by learning new vocabulary and grammar.

This class will teach you about basic Chinese political and cultural affairs in the Chinese language, as well as common grammar structures with which you can discuss these ideas

If you would like a sample of the material, check out the textbook

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strength was that the frequent quizzes in the class ensured that the students understood the material. Furthermore, the usage of the new grammar patterns allowed students to see how they were supposed to be used. However, the weakness was that there wasn't much exposure to multiple fluent speakers of Chinese, but rather only a single teacher, which meant that students would only get to see one person's style of communication.

Strengths: good teaching
Weaknesses: a bit repetitive

Su Wei is an excellent teacher who makes his students feel cared for as people! His stories are very engaging and provide a rich way to include and expand on new vocabulary that we learn. The structure of the course (weekly quizzes) is also excellent in helping students memorize the content better. I truly think Yale has one of the best departments for learning Chinese!
Strengths: tests are very predictable, though quizzes are very often

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would wholeheartedly recommend this course to another student because I felt like I learned a lot. I got much better at Chinese and consequently feel much more fluent when I read, write, speak, and listen to it.

Yes! I think Yale's Chinese department is one of its best departments. The faculty are excellent and the curriculum is designed in a way that is both interesting and relevant to current affairs. A great way to learn about Chinese culture and also expand your vocabulary. Also driven heavily by student engagement, and so you can get as much out of the course as you put into it! Lots of opportunities to speak, and even more opportunities to write vocabulary!

Yes, Chinese at Yale is one of the best. Integrates conversation as well as written assignments, and the teachers always organize cultural opportunities outside of class too (i.e caligraphy club, lunar new year celebrations)
